conclusion: At T = 200 K, p ≈ 0.5 × 10⁵ Pa = 5.0 × 10⁴ Pa from the p-T graph.
At T = 400 K, p ≈ 1.0 × 10⁵ Pa = 1.0 × 10⁵ Pa from the p-T graph.
Pressure is proportional to temperature in the plotted range; the line through these points passes through the origin indicating ideal-gas behavior at constant volume.
At T = 400 K, V ≈ 2.5 m³ from the V-T graph.
At T = 600 K, V ≈ 3.0 m³ from the V-T graph.
Between 400 K and 600 K the volume changes while the gas continues to obey pV = nRT.
Using the ideal-gas law and consistency of the number of moles: n = p₁V₁/(RT₁) at T₁ = 400 K, p₁ = 1.0 × 10⁵ Pa, V₁ = 2.5 m³.
At T₂ = 600 K, V₂ = 3.0 m³, the same n gives: p₂ = nRT₂ / V₂.
The pressure of the gas when the temperature reaches 600 K is approximately 1.3 × 10⁵ Pa.
